what: Simple Double-ML implementation with cross-fitting — DMLReg
title: Simple Double-ML implementation with cross-fitting — DMLReg
Simple Double-ML implementation with cross-fitting — DMLReg
code: DMLReg(x, d, y, dreg, yreg, nfold = 5)

title: Simple Double-ML implementation with cross-fitting — DMLReg
text: x Matrix covariates d treatment variable y dependent variable dreg function wraps learner - e.g. glmnet - pscore yreg function wraps learner - e.g. glmnet - outcome regression D vector factor variables partialed nfolds number folds cross fitting

title: Simple Double-ML implementation with cross-fitting — DMLReg
code: if (FALSE) { dreg = \(x, d) cv.glmnet(x, d, alpha = 1) yreg = \(x, y) cv.glmnet(x, y, alpha = 1) res = DMLReg(x = x, d = d, y = y, dreg = dreg, yreg = yreg, nfold = 5) }

code: binscatter(   fmla,   key_var,   data,   plotraw = TRUE,   bins = 20,   rawdata_colour = "black",   rawdata_alpha = 0.2,   rawdata_size = 0.5,   linfit_width = 0.6,   linfit_colour = "blue",   cef_point_size = 1,   cef_point_colour = "red",   ci_colour = "gray",   ci_alpha = 0.3 )

title: R implementation of binned scatterplot and CEF plotter, with added options for cluster variance — binscatter
text: fmla FELM formula *string* key_var X axis variable CEF data dataframe plotraw T underlying scatterplot plotted bins number bins rawdata_colour Colour Rawdata rawdata_alpha Alpha Rawdata rawdata_size Size Rawdata linfit_width width linear fit linfit_colour colour linear fit cef_point_size Size binscatter points cef_point_colour Colour binscatter points ci_colour Colour CI ribbon ci_alpha Alpha CI ribbon

title: R implementation of binned scatterplot and CEF plotter, with added options for cluster variance — binscatter

code: formula_fixest(y = 'mpg', X = c('hp', 'drat'), D = c('wt', 'vs')) #> mpg ~ hp + drat | wt + vs #> <environment: 0x56544bd2f968> formula_fixest(y = 'mpg', X = c('hp', 'drat'), W = 'gear', Z = c('cyl', 'carb'), D = c('wt', 'vs')) #> mpg ~ hp + drat | wt + vs | gear ~ cyl + carb #> <environment: 0x56544bd9a050>

code: formula_lfe(y = 'mpg', X = c('hp', 'drat'), D = c('wt', 'vs')) #> mpg ~ hp + drat | wt + vs | 0 | 0 #> <environment: 0x56544dd1d758> formula_lfe(y = 'mpg', X = c('hp', 'drat'), W = 'gear', Z = c('cyl', 'carb'), D = c('wt', 'vs'), C = c('cyl', 'wt')) #> mpg ~ hp + drat | wt + vs | (gear ~ cyl + carb) | cyl + wt #> <environment: 0x56544ddb9fa8>

what: Experimental data from the job training program first studied by LaLonde (1986) — lalonde.exp
title: Experimental data from the job training program first studied by LaLonde (1986) — lalonde.exp
text: dataset units experimental evaluation job training program. Subset units two years pre-treatment income data. age - age years. education - number years schooling. black - 1 black, 0 otherwise. hispanic - 1 Hispanic, 0 otherwise. married - 1 married, 0 otherwise. nodegree - 1 high school degree, 0 otherwise. re74 - earnings ($) 1974. re75 - earnings ($) 1975. re78 - earnings ($) 1978. u74 - 1 unemployed 1974, 0 otherwise. u75 - 1 unemployed 1975, 0 otherwise. treat - 1 treated, 0 otherwise.

title:
Multi-core replicate.
Use multiple cores for repeated evaluation of an expression. — mcReplicate

Multi-core replicate.
Use multiple cores for repeated evaluation of an expression. — mcReplicate
code: one_sim = \(n = 100, control_prob = 0.1, rel_effect = 0.01) {   treat_prob = control_prob + (control_prob * rel_effect)   cy = rbinom(n = n, size = 1, prob = control_prob)   ty = rbinom(n = n, size = 1, prob = treat_prob)   mean(ty) - mean(cy) } mcReplicate(10, one_sim(), mc.cores = 2) #>  #>  [1]  0.08 -0.04  0.05  0.12  0.05 -0.04  0.09 -0.01 -0.02 -0.01

data(lalonde.psid); data(lalonde.exp); y = "re78"; w = "treat"; xs = setdiff(colnames(lalonde.psid), c(y, w)) cat("ATE in experimental sample 
") #> ATE in experimental sample  reg_adjust(lalonde.exp, 'treat', 're78', xs, "ATE") #> OLS estimation, Dep.
